video.title: Google Cloud Digital Leader Certification Course - Pass the Exam!
video.description:
Prepare for the Google Cloud Digital Leader Certification and pass!

✏️ Developed by Andrew Brown of ExamPro.
🔗 https://www.youtube.com/ExamProChannel
🔗 https://www.exampro.co

☁️ Intro
🎤 0:00:00 Intro
🎤 0:13:29 Exam Guide Breakdown
🎤 0:22:11 Additional GCP Resources

☁️ Cloud Concepts

topLevelComment.author: Astral Fields
topLevelComment.text: Passed this week. Make sure to focus on 'everything' that the exam guidance mentions. There was even one question from the Google Cloud Adoption Framework. They have really tried hard to include questions in the exam that are contained within the official guide and official courses, which is of course good. But if you pass only the official courses and guides, it is also not enough. You need to understand in which situations things like DataWarehouse, DataProc, BigQuery etc are used. All the questions are situational, which makes the exam relatively harder than Az-900 and AWS (I have both).

topLevelComment.author: Natasza Nowakowska
topLevelComment.text: Exam is way easier, not so much technical details, no extend scenarios and multi choice questions, just single choice. Usually it's a direct question about which service/product does this and that, majority it's just 1-2 sentence scenario like: travel agency decides to share their social media content, what should they use etc. If you have a general knowledge about cloud, security, ML, access, databases (including all data products BigQuery, Cloud Spanner etc), and some products especially Apigee, Kubernetes, Compute Engine, VMs solutions, Anthos, Bare Metal etc. then you will pass. I would say it doesn't go into that much details anymore, if you don't know the answer just go with common sense and elimination method :)

replies.author: Rug

Finally, i tested my preparation over some free examples on internet (seek "exam cloud digital leader").

topLevelComment.author: Saihati
topLevelComment.text: Ok, I've just finished my exam. Don't know the result yet; they told me to wait up to 10 days to get the result (pass/fail). I'll update it here. So, this video content is outdated! As a few of people said in comments, exam was changed, and they won't ask heavily technical questions. You still need to know about GKE, Compute Engine, App Engine, Cloud Run, what is a container and what is a VM. You also need to know the difference between Cloud Spanner and Cloud SQL. Learn about data storage solutions, differences and purposes for databases, data warehouses and data lakes. Study SLA, SLO. Didn't get any question on greenfield/brownfield, but I guess it's just random. They also asked about cloud treace and cloud debugger, and a few questions about security, and organization structure. Oh yes, and 2 questions about phishing and malware. Altogether 50 questions. Guys, I bought several exam dumps over the internet; they are all outdated and useless! Don't waste your money on those. The exam is way easier; it really covers information you get from google course itself. Learn it, take notes, and try practice exam questions; they are very similar to what you get on the actual exam. I'll be checking this thread for a few days, ask your questions here, and I'll try to answer.

replies.author: GrindingisLife

replies.author: GrindingisLife

replies.author: Just A Tip
replies.text: @Saihati hey what all sources you use?

replies.author: Saihati
replies.text: Ok, I've passed the exam and got my certificate. So, again, for anyone who is trying to prepare for the Google Cloud Digital Leader exam in August 2022, my advice is to stick with the official Google route. Make sure you really know and understand everything they explain in their video and learn all pdf they provide. That is really the only thing you will need on the exam. Again, all exam questions I saw on the internet are highly technical and do not align with real questions on the exam. Good luck, everyone. It really wasn't that hard to prepare and pass.

1 ques was an app has 99.999% availability. How many time it is down? (5min, 500 min, 5 hour or 5 day) - stupid question but came in exam...

replies.author: A
replies.text: @Loves RainyDay Remember - greenfield - means you want to make application completely from scratch. brownfield means you have existing app and you want to move it to cloud so here you are reusing existing app by moving it. They had 2 question on this scenario and my exam was only 2 weeks ago.

topLevelComment.author: canadiancissp
topLevelComment.text:
Thank you for the video!  I want to point out a potential small tiny mistake.

At 2:13:13 "Cloud Storage" you mentioned that the durability is "nine nines". The slide shows 11 nines. The "nines" are calculated by adding the digits on both sides of the decimal point.

If you have 99 followed by the decimal point and then 9 additional "nines" (like in the slide), the total is 11 nines.

If the durability is "nine nines" then you need to correct the slide by removing 2 digits. Maybe someone already raised this point and you already commented? I could not find it. 

Thank you again! All the best!

topLevelComment.author: Diego Alves Rodrigues
topLevelComment.text: One important distinction about the deployment model of Cloud Computing called Private Cloud to the On-Premises Hosting is that although you can call Private Cloud as On-Premise, is "On-Premisses" Cloud. To be considered an On-Premisses Cloud you need to meet, in your On-Premisses Hosting, all the essential characteristics of cloud computing. Just because you have servers on your company and run them, it's not a Private Cloud. I hope this could help somebody confused.

topLevelComment.author: CptSupermrkt
topLevelComment.text: I just wanted to chime in here and say that I passed this exam today, and I only did two things: watch this video from start to finish, and use the Google-provided CSP comparison table to see how AWS services map to GCP.  I have AWS DevOps Eng Pro and so to be honest I was kind of expecting this exam to be a cakewalk, but despite passing, it was more challenging than I was expecting.  The difficulty of the questions was all over the place, kinda a mess to be honest: you might get a question that essentially asks like what a specific service is/done (i.e. super easy, what you'd expect on an introductory exam), then the next question might be something like about external identity provider integration and exactly where/what resource you would modify in the console to implement that integration (i.e. something I'd expect someone with like 3-6 months of hands-on experience to know).  And then the next question you might be right back to something along the lines of, "what is a network?"  In any event, this video was invaluable, so thank you.

replies.author: RayzorBeak
replies.text: I agree. I have 3 AWS certifications, and multiple Azure and other Cloud certs, and I was unable to pass this exam in May when it came out of Beta. All over the place and to make matters worse, Google doesn't provide a score, a score report, or any of that. They just state "pass" or "fail" and that's their entire feedback. I will go for it again later this Fall.

replies.author: Simplythrusting
replies.text: https://www.exampro.co/ has over 100+ exam practice questions that are very helpful. I took the exam and passed it. They only grade you Pass or Fail, no score evaluation. There is also https://www.whizlabs.com/google-cloud-certified-cloud-digital-leader/ gives you 20 free questions. The goal is to know the differences between each Google product/service and know which one is best to use in each business scenario. The course is still pretty new so it's difficult to good exam questions. The quiklabs training on Google resource is pretty terrible because there is little to no transferable information that was on the exam there. Overall ExamPro is a very well built course that covers more than what is needed.
